occurrences.line_text: And their resistlesse rigour did eschew.
With so huge rigour, that his mortall speare
A Lions clawes, with powre and rigour clad,
Ne once for ruth their rigour they releast,
And did the rigour of his doome represse;
And to renue the rigour of his smart:
Mourning the rigour of her malady,
And cruell rigour her did much molest;
(O too high ditty for my simple rime.)
Ne spareth he the gentle Poets rime,
As he were charmed with inchaunted rimes,
My ragged rimes are all too rude and bace,
But ah my rimes too rude and rugged arre,
This odious argument my rimes should shend,
My looser rimes (I wote) doth sharply wite,
How may these rimes, so rude as doth appeare,
Here well I weene, when as these rimes be red
Therfore do you my rimes keep better measure,
The which Rinaldo drunck in happie howre,
Her wrizled skin as rough, as maple rind,
That all the woods with doubled Eccho ring,
The neighbour woods around with hollow murmur ring.
That with their horrour heauen and earth did ring,
And made the forrest ring, as it would riue in twaine.
Vpgath'ring, in her bosome she comprized,
When one so oft a night did ring his matins bell.
Conceiued by a ring, which she him sent,
All was through vertue of the ring he wore,
Loe here this ring, which shall thy warrant bee,
Into the rest, which round about you ring,
And taking from her hand a ring of gould,
And Calidore should lead the ring, as hee
All raunged in a ring, and dauncing in delight.
All they without were raunged in a ring,
Amidst a ring most richly well enchaced,
That all the castle ringed with the clap.
And oftentimes loud strokes, and ringing sounds
Ne spared he to giue her gold and rings:
About her necke, or rings of rushes plight;
Gold, amber, yuorie, perles, owches, rings,
Well was that rings great vertue knowen to all,
Through that rings vertue, that with vigour new,
They all gan shout aloud, that all the heauen rings.
First rings his siluer Bell t'each sleepy wight,
His life he led in lawlesse riotise;
Through wastfull Pride, and wanton Riotise,
Consuming Riotise, and guilty Dread
The image of superfluous riotize,
In which was nothing riotous nor vaine?
And round about him preace in riotous aray.
Then rip vp griefe, where it may not auaile,
To rip vp wrong, that battell once hath tried;
There sate a man of ripe and perfect age,
At last ripe age bad him surrender late
In which he dyde, made ripe for death by eld,
Ambrose and Vther did ripe years attaine,
Ripe yeares of reason, my right to maintaine.
He was to weete a man of full ripe yeares,
Some like faire Emeraudes, not yet well ripened.
Till to her dew perfection she was ripened.
Should reap the haruest, ere it ripened were;
In which when she to perfect ripenesse grew,
Which when to ripenesse due they growen arre,
Till that to ripenesse of mans state they grew:
Vntill the ripenesse of mans yeares he raught;
Till it to ripenesse grew, and forth to honour burst.
Till he to perfect ripenesse grew, and then
And with her right the riper fruit did reach,
Who seemd of riper yeares, then th'other Swaine,
Of ripest yeares, and haires all hoarie gray,
Of the Riphoean hils, to her reueald
And to him cals, Rise rise vnhappy Swaine,
And to him cals, Rise rise vnhappy Swaine,
So new this new-borne knight to battell new did rise.
Now therefore Ladie, rise out of your paine,
So vp he let him rise, who with grim looke
Ne suffred them to rise or greater grow,
And to those brethren said, Rise rise by liue,
And to those brethren said, Rise rise by liue,
Some to remoue the scum, as it did rise;
Fairely to rise, and her adorned hed
The surging waters like a mountaine rise,
And each the other from to rise restraine;
A gloomy groue of mirtle trees did rise,
That counsell pleasd: then Paridell did rise,
Thus she at length perswaded him to rise,
Into the inner roome, from whence they first did rise.
How to preuent the perill that mote rise,
Whence litle lust he had to rise againe.
And bad him rise, or surely he should die.
That rules the Seas, and makes them rise or fall;
And wested twice, where he ought rise aright.
Or weigh the light, that in the East doth rise;
To rise through all the Temple sodainely,
Now rise againe, at this your ioyous sight.
So suffring him to rise, he made him sweare
Then vp he made him rise, and forward fare,
Whence he assayd to rise, but could not for his hurt.
And let him rise. Then thus the Prince gan say;
That wild the damzell rise; the day did now expyre.
A Tigre forth out of the wood did rise,
Or rise against the remnant at their will;
Like ghost late risen from his graue agryz'd,
And twice hath risen, where he now doth West,
And rising forth out of her baser bowre,
As faire Aurora rising hastily,
There shall a Rauen far from rising Sunne,
And rising vp, gan streight to ouerlooke,
And odours rising from the altars flame.
Calidore rising vp as fresh as day,
Who rising vp at last in ghastly wize,
In so ritch weedes and seeming glorious show,
Or Cybeles franticke rites haue made them mad;
With sacred rites and vowes for euer to abyde.
Had with due rites and dolorous lament
There wanted nought but few rites to be donne,
Vppon the rites and daily sacrifize,
Throwes forth vpon the riuage round about him nere.
The riuall slaine, the victour through the flood
His sonne Riuallo his dead roome did supply,
That euen they, the which his riuals were,
So riu'd her trembling hart, and wicked end did make.
So hugely stroke, that it the steele did riue,
Were wont to riue steele plates, and helmets hew,
And made the forrest ring, as it would riue in twaine.
That his deepe wounded hart in two did riue,
And riue with thousand throbs thy thrilled brest;
Or riue in twaine: which when that Lady bright
But that continuall battery will riue,
And the sharpe steele doth riue her hart in tway,
What time his people into partes did riue,
That seem'd a rocke of Diamond it could riue,
As if that euery dint the ghost would riue
And from her griping pounce the greedy prey doth riue.
For very ruth, which did it almost riue,
That seem'd a marble rocke asunder could haue riue.
Of life him selfe, and hart-strings of an ï¿½ fï¿½EUR gle riued.
That seem'd both shield & plate it would haue riued;
Yet nathemore the steele a sunder riued,
Much more then earst, and would haue algates riued
But riued were like rotten wood a sunder,
The soule had sure out of his bodie riued,
That stony hart could riuen haue in twaine,
Had riuen many a brest with pikehead square;
Through riuen cloudes and molten firmament;
Forth gushed, like fresh water streame from riuen rocke.
Whilome doth rancle in my riuen brest,
These words she breathed forth from riuen chest;
An open passage through his riuen brest,
Her bleeding brest, and riuen bowels gor'd,
And all within the riuen walls were hung
Like as the lightning brond from riuen skie,
And all adowne their riuen sides did ronne.
Which from their riuen sides forth gushed like a flood.
Had riuen bene, and all her hart strings brast,
From whence the riuer Dee as siluer cleene
A gushing riuer of blacke goarie blood,
The Amazon huge riuer now found trew?
Through midst thereof a little riuer rold,
Came to a riuer, by whose vtmost brim
That is the riuer of Cocytus deepe,
Within the riuer, which the same did hyde:
Foreby a riuer in a pleasaunt dale,
Foreby the Riuer, that whylome was hight
Adowne the rolling riuer she did poure,
And euery riuer eke his course forbeares
And in the midst a little riuer plaide
And a long bloudy riuer through them rayld,
And vnderneath, the riuer rolling still
And that huge Riuer, which doth beare his name
Slew cruelly, and in the riuer drowned quight.
For in the selfe same riuer, where he late
And nam'd the riuer of his wretched fate;
And vnderneath the same a riuer flowes,
Into the riuer, where he drunke his deadly last.
And carelesly into the riuer goth,
So to the riuers side they both together far'd.
Which Greece and Asian riuers stained with their blood.
Toward the land; two riuers bound the rest.
Adowne their sides like litle riuers stremed,
Doth burne the earth, and boyled riuers drie,
As that in riuers swim, or brookes doe wade.
And after him the famous riuers came,
All little Riuers, which owe vassallage
And many riuers taking vnder hand
Ne thence the Irishe Riuers absent were:
In three great riuers ran, and many countreis scowrd.
Of Gods, of Nymphs, of riuers yet vnred:
So from the Ocean all riuers spring,
Downe in a dale forby a riuers syde,
But comming to the riuers side, he found
Her shattered ribs in thousand peeces riues,
Yet of those fearefull women none durst rize,
No powre he had to stirre, nor will to rize.
There chaunced to the Princes hand to rize,
That from his sides some noble chyld should rize,
Who thinkes from me his sorrow all doth rize.
Who now come to himselfe, yet would not rize,
The morrow next the Prince did early rize,
Such was that hag, which with Duessa roade,
This day, as he and I together roade
He roar'd aloud, whiles life forsooke his stubborne brest.
Of many beasts, that roard outrageously,
That made the rockes to roare, as they were rent.
Thereat he roared for exceeding paine,
Leaue roaring, when in rage he for reuenge did earne.
That roaring all with rage, did lowd requere
And throw in raging sea with roaring threat.
With that they heard a roaring hideous sound,
An hideous roaring farre away they heard,
Eftsoones the roaring billowes still abid,
The roaring billowes in their proud disdaine,
With roaring rage; and dashing on all sides,
Who it to rob and ransacke did intend.
That pitty did the Virgins hart of patience rob.
For sacrilege me seem'd the Church to rob,
To search out those, that vsd to rob and steale,
Now comest thou to rob my house vnmand,
Wont to robbe Churches of their ornaments,
It booted nought to thinke, to robbe him of his pray.
And many wilde woodmen, which robbe and rend
His robbed whelpes, and at the last them fond
But read what wicked hand hath robbed mee
That all the rest it seem'd they robbed bare
And hearts quite robbed with so glorious sight,
That robbed all the countrie there about,
Robbed her people, that full rich had beene,
Thou canst preserue from wrong and robbery?
And robd of royall robes, and purple pall,
And robd the world of threasure endlesse deare,
And robd of reason, towards her him bore,
Which they from many long had robd and rent,
And robd the Chancell, and the deskes downe threw,
As to haue robde you of that manly hew?
Had spred her purple robe through deawy aire,
But spoile her of her scarlot robe, and let her fly.
And purple robe gored with many a wound;
In robe of lilly white she was arayd,
And took on him the robe of Emperoure:
Without or robe, or rag, to hide his shame.
Ease, on his robe in golden letters cyphered.
As with a robe, with her owne siluer haire,
All decked in a robe of watchet hew,
Her linnen stole to robe of scarlet red,
With royall robes and gorgeous array,
And robd of royall robes, and purple pall,
The rest was all in yellow robes arayed still.
Arayd in antique robes downe to the ground,
In ragged robes, and filthy disaray,
And richly clad in robes of royaltye,
There were rent robes, and broken scepters plast,
All clad in linnen robes with siluer hemd;
In roiall robes, and many Iewels dight,
Robs reason of her due regalitie
The hartlesse Hind and Robucke to dismay,
But ouerleapes them all, like Robucke light,
And the Robuckes in flight to ouertake,
They on this rock are rent, and sunck in helplesse wawes.
And down the rock him throwing, in the sea him dround.
A trickling streame from high rocke tumbling downe
So stood these twaine, vnmoued as a rocke,
An hidden rocke escaped hath vnwares,
As rocke of Diamond stedfast euermore.
Hewen out of Adamant rocke with engines keene,
Forth gushed, like fresh water streame from riuen rocke.
As if in Adamant rocke it had bene pight.
Built on a rocke adioyning to the seas:
On th'other side an hideous Rocke is pight,
On th'other side, they saw that perilous Rocke,
For thy, this hight The Rocke of vile Reproch,
To shunne Rocke of Reproch, and it as death to dred.
On th'other side an high rocke toured still,
And on the rocke the waues breaking aloft,
Vnder a rocke that lyes a little space
From vnder that deepe Rocke most horribly rebounds.
That could haue made a rocke of stone to rew,
Vnder a mightie rocke, gainst which do raue
Sad Clotho held the rocke, the whiles the thrid
As fast as water-sprinckles gainst a rocke are dasht.
That seem'd a rocke of Diamond it could riue,
Deepe in the bottome of an huge great rocke
For all about that rocke the sea did flow.
And romed round about the rocke in vaine,
Who mou'd no more therewith, then when a rocke
Vpon a rocke, and holding forth on hie
Vpon a rocke with horrible dismay,
Which wonned in a rocke not farre away,
And eke the rocke, in which he wonts to dwell,
Vnto the rocke, where was the villains won:
Vnto the rocke, and there vpon the soyle
Vp to the rocke he ran, and thereon flew
That seem'd a marble rocke asunder could haue riue.
Doth belch out flames, and rockes in peeces broke,
Lurking in rockes and caues farre vnder ground,
Of the rough rockes, do diuersly disease,
Out of the rockes and caues adioyning nye,
No lesse, then rockes, (as trauellers informe,)
That on the rockes he fell so flit and light,
Of that rockes fall, which euer and anon
That made the rockes to roare, as they were rent.
Doe pearce the rockes, and hardest marble weares;
Both ouer rockes, and hilles, and euery place,
That all the woods and rockes nigh to that way,
So downe he fell, as an huge rockie clift,
Till that he came vnto a rockie hill,
Doth roll adowne the rocks, and fall with fearefull drift.
And lurkt in rocks and caues long vnespide.
That high trees ouerthrew, and rocks in peeces tore.
And both from rocks and flats it selfe could wisely saue.
Learning his ship from those white rocks to saue,
On the rough rocks, or on the sandy shallowes,
That the hard rocks could scarse from teares refraine,
These towring rocks, which reach vnto the skie,
Through woods, and rocks, and mountaines they did draw
By reason of the streight, and rocks among,
Mongst rocks and caues, where she enrold doth lie
And all the Graces rockt her cradle being borne.
High growing on the top of rocky clift,
Did hang vpon the ragged rocky knees;
Like an huge caue, hewne out of rocky clift,
And sitting downe vpon the rocky shore,
And in a rocky caue as wight forlorne,
In a strong rocky Caue, which is they say,
That ruth it moued in the rocky stone,
But his hard rocky hart for no entreating
Not farre from hence, vppon yond rocky hill,
On either side disparted with his rod,
That in his hand a white rod menaged,
Caduceus the rod of Mercury,
Stretch her white rod ouer the Belgicke shore,
In her right hand a rod of peace shee bore,
Like to the rod which Maias sonne doth wield,
Shee with her rod did softly smite the raile,
But that the Goddesse with her rod him backe did beat.
And euer as he rode, his hart did earne
A louely Ladie rode him faire beside,
And after him she rode with so much speede
So forth they rode, he feining seemely merth,
With whom as once I rode accompanyde,
And by his side rode loathsome Gluttony,
Still as he rode, he somewhat still did eat,
And next to him rode lustfull Lechery,
And next to him malicious Enuie rode,
Still as he rode, he gnasht his teeth, to see
Rode Sathan, with a smarting whip in hand,
Emongst the rest rode that false Lady faire,
For we be come vnto a quiet rode,
Vpright he rode, and in his siluer shield
That rode in golden sell with single spere,
Vpon a Tygre swift and fierce he rode,
And him beside an aged Squire there rode,
Then to the next she rode, & downe the next did beare.
The Redcrosse knight diuerst, but forth rode Britomart.
So forth she rode without repose or rest,
But forward rode, and kept her readie way
Him to poursew, but to the Ladie rode,
And afterwardes, on what aduenture now he rode.
Alone he rode without his Paragone;
So forth he rode, as his aduenture fell;
Lo thus they rode, till at the last they spide
With whom as they thus rode accompanide,
So well accorded forth they rode together
Two knights, that lincked rode in louely wise,
And strange aduentures, all the way they rode:
So as he rode with them accompanide,
And all that while, where so they rode or came,
Vnto whose rescue forth rode Paridell;
On whom remounting, fiercely forth he rode,
Against her rode, full of despiteous ire,
Till on a day as through that wood he rode,
So forth she rode vppon her ready way,
Sadly she rode, and neuer word did say,
And rode him selfe vppon his first intent:
And euer as she rode, her eye was backeward bent.
That after those two former rode apace,
On which long way he rode, ne euer day did rest.
Tho as they rode together on their way,
And forth together rode a comely couplement.
So forth they rode together all in troupe,
He found the gate wyde ope, and in he rode,
So as they rode, he saw the way all dyde
Of stealth and spoile, and making nightly rode
For he was long, and swift as any Roe,
And flying fast as Roebucke through the fen,
And roiall pompe, which there long hidden lay,
Who gaue him roiall giftes and riches rare,
In roiall robes, and many Iewels dight,
Vpon him tooke the roiall high degree,
And leauing home, to roiall court I sought;
Through midst thereof a little riuer rold,
And at her feete a Crocodile was rold,
Doth roll adowne the rocks, and fall with fearefull drift.
Did roll too highly, and too often glaunce,
To stirre and roll them, like a womans eyes;
And on his head a roll of linnen plight,
Who rolled on an heape lay still in swound,
The antique rolles, which there lye hidden still,
His chamber all was hangd about with rolles,
And rolles of Elfin Emperours,
To whom those rolles, layd vp in heauen aboue,
The rolling billowes beat the ragged shore,
And rolling downe, great Neptune doth dismay;
Adowne the rolling riuer she did poure,
The waues come rolling, and the billowes rore
With that the rolling sea resounding soft,
His rolling eyes did neuer rest in place,
Came to the caue, and rolling thence the stone,
And vnderneath, the riuer rolling still
There was the Liffy rolling downe the lea,
His tombling billowes rolls with gentle rore:
That Romaine Monarch built a brasen wall,
The antique ruines of the Romaines fall:
Tybris, renowmed for the Romaines fame,
The Romane legion in dreadfull fight:
Whom Romane warres, which now foure hundred yeares,
Which that rich Romane of white marble wrought,
Such as that prudent Romane well inuented,
Till the prowd Romanes him disquieted,
Soone after this the Romanes him warrayd;
Did driue the Romanes to the weaker side,
Nor dred of Romanes, then was Aruirage,
Whilest Romanes dayly did the weake subdew:
And gainst the Romanes bent their proper powre,
Which when the Romanes heard, they hither sent
With dreadfull noise, and hollow rombling rore,
And brasen Caudrons thou shalt rombling heare,
Soft rombling brookes, that gentle slomber drew;
That sacked Rome too dearely did assay,
T'ambitious Rome, and did their rule obay,
Of Rome againe, who hither hastly sent
Who afterward was Emperour of Rome;
Ne byte before, but rome from place to place,
Exploits made Rome to quake, stout Guendolen,
Till Romulus renewing it, to Rome remoud.
Of fatall Thebes, of Rome that raigned long,
But walkt abrode, and round about did rome,
She forth did rome, whether her rage her bore,
To lodge, then in the saluage fields to rome.
Saue Beares, Lions, & Buls, which romed them around.
And romed round about the rocke in vaine,
At last as there he romed vp and downe,
About her head, still roming here and there;
But at her rompe she growing had behind
Great Romulus the Grandsyre of them all,
Till Romulus renewing it, to Rome remoud.
Early and late it rong, at euening and at prime.
Did shrieke alowd, that through the house it rong,
Gan shout aloud, that vnto heauen it rong;
Then linger, till the glasse be all out ronne?
Within a wandring Island, that doth ronne
But straggling plots, which to and fro do ronne
But if thee list to see thy Courser ronne,
Retyrd their steeds, to ronne in euen race:
There might ye see loose steeds at randon ronne,
And all adowne their riuen sides did ronne.
The trompets sound; then all together ronne.
Toward the same incessantly did ronne,
And dry vp all the water, which doth ronne
Till Trompart ronning hastily, him did stay,
And fiercely ronning to that Lady trew,
Deckt all the roofe, and shadowing the roode,
Both roofe, and floore, and wals were all of gold,
The massy roofe, and riches huge sustayne,
The roofe hereof was arched ouer head,
And through the roofe of her strong brasen towre
The roofe vp high was reared from the ground,
Deckt all the roofe, and shadowing the roode,
And skin all withered like a dryed rooke,
Full enuious that night so long his roome did fill.
And he, that points the Centonell his roome,
And yeeld his roome to sad succeeding night,
Thence brought th[m] to the second roome, whose wals
Of those that roome was full, and them among
But Alma thence the[m] led to th'hindmost roome of three.
His sonne Riuallo his dead roome did supply,
Octauius here lept into his roome,
And yeeld her roome to day, that can it gouerne well.
But forward with bold steps into the next roome went.
Much fairer, then the former, was that roome,
Into the inner roome, from whence they first did rise.
For thy, from that same roome not to depart
Ne liuing wight she saw in all that roome,
Into a lower roome, and by and by
Went vp the hall, that was a large wyde roome,
He fled from roome to roome, from place to place,
He fled from roome to roome, from place to place,
Therein were diuerse roomes, and diuerse stages,
These three in these three roomes did sundry dwell,
At last she spyde at that roomes vpper end,
Returning backe, those goodly roomes, which erst
Of falshood, and root of Duessaes race.
But yet the cause and root of all his ill,
Occasion, the root of all wrath and despight.
Whose root and stalke so bitter yet did tast,
Thou art the root and nurse of bitter cares,
Thou art the root of all that ioyous is,
Who was the root and worker of her woe:
Rent by the root; which he so sternely shooke,
The roote of all your care, and wretched plight,
And deeme them roote of all disquietnesse;
